text: okay hi everyone so since yesterday I
talked about sexual orientation I
thought it was appropriate for me to add
a little note about transgender
employees because a lot of times in LGBT
research people say LGBT in the title
and then when you get to the methods
section they say well actually we didn't
include any transgender people but
someone else should do that so I didn't
want to also do that by covering sexual
orientation and not transgender issues
so here we go mine's more conceptual so
words matter these are the words we
frequently see with regard to gender but
even though we're so used to using them
I believe that these words are limiting
I believe they've limited me they've
limited you they've limited us as a
society they can find people to being
one thing a ball of stereotypes and
punishments for stepping out of line
with these stereotypes to being a man or
a woman a he or she just and never both
but we know that gender doesn't always
work that way in fact in our studies
we've started asking about gender on a
continuum as opposed to a checkbox and
what do we find we find variability men
actually rate themselves as being
somewhat feminine and sometimes the same
on both females do the same thing and so
what we're finding here is that
transgender individuals have highlighted
and genderqueer individuals have
highlighted for a long time that these
words are troublesome they're rigid and
our participants are telling us that the
check box is too rigid they don't
account for variability within category
they don't allow for new and different
forms of gender expression to exist even
for those who are non-transgender these
forms of words and language are limiting
and binding they have stereotypes
associated with them we know them men
are viewed as being strong and willful a
gen take decisive women are viewed as
being nurturing caring focused on
building relationships and so while many
people fight to preserve these words
while many people feel these words are
natural if you don't believe me go look
at my TED talk on transgender issues and
read the comments section people are
accusing me of going against nature
going against God etc etc um so while
many people fight to preserve these
words I believe that they are just words
we can change them and we might want to
because these words are dangerous
they're loaded they're out they are in
some ways a trap but I don't believe
that their final we can get past these
words there are ways that we might
change
language to be more inclusive there are
ways we might change our language to
reflect what we are now seeing in
society brave individuals who are
highlighting that our categories are
ever-present but they are not
everlasting they don't work in the way
we need them to all the time they don't
work in a way that supports freedom of
choice and freedom from stereotypes but
gendered language doesn't have to be a
prison just as we invented gendered
words we can invent words that are
inclusive we choose our words and in
choosing our words carefully we can
create a language that's more inclusive
if you think it's hard to invent words
think about how quickly slang terms
catch on my students use words many
words that did not exist when I was a
student but everyone can interpret them
we all know what they mean and they're
being used just like that gendered
language could catch on in the same
changing gendered language could catch
on in the same way we could be part of
the revolution of using language that
includes individuals for whom language
doesn't currently work and for those who
don't wish to associate with the
historic connotations that come along
with gender divisions within our
language and our society if there's a
will to change language and if we use
past precedent both with regard to words
that have fallen out of favor and words
that have found their way into our
vernacular there is a way we have
banished lots of commonly used words
from language before and we can do it
again of course this will be faced with
resistance but instead of face but
instead of resisting change agents in
society we should value them I would
strongly argue that the almost 2 percent
of the population that identifies as
transgender or gender queer are not
making trouble in attempting to open our
eyes to new ways of using language they
are highlighting a place in society
where our traditions are not working
instead of ousting the minority view
from the conversation which is what we
frequently do I believe that it's time
to make them an already group the focus
if our current language is limiting some
people let's remove the limits so I want
to tell you a story for my research I do
a lot of qualitative and quantitative
research in the area of transgender
employment and I can tell you a story of
someone who goes by Z a friend of mine
also participate in the study who is
tired of being defined by social
expectations for their gender expression
Z wears clothes that are stereotypically
associated with both genders even
creates new clothes that are gender
creative has sexual relationships with
individuals who express gender in all
different ways and is highly successful
in their field of study Z is very
intelligent and in my opinion is an
innovator if you go to any business
conference in any school on any
continent you will now hear scholars and
practitioners talking about
out-of-the-box thinking that the
future belongs to those who aren't
afraid to go against the grain to shake
things up to create something new that
the world didn't know existed but the
flip side of this is that zis story also
as a negative side Z has faced a lot of
employment discrimination despite their
many talents this story for me
highlights that in the same arena in
which we value or say we value
innovators when it comes to gender we
value traditionalists or those who fit
with some form of neo-traditional ism
that has become acceptable with the
passage of time so I believe that
innovation is not best practice when you
turn it on and off it's best practice as
a way of life however for some reason
when it comes to gender even those who
fancy themselves to be fathers and
mothers of innovation at work are still
very tied to the ideas of fathers
mothers and a traditionally rooted
practice of gender within organizations
so now some questions if you think back
on your life and the way you've loved it
think back in your choice in the way
you've made them how would you have
thought of yourself differently if you
are not defined as a he or she and I
want you to think about where you would
be right now if you hadn't been assigned
that from day one thank you
